text:
Situation A. Drawing Marbles – Theoretical Probabilities

Ms. Tsao’s class had a conjecture about the sum of the theoretical probabilities for an event in the Initial Challenge. They claimed that the sum of the theoretical probabilities for an event is always one.

Ms. Tsao suggests they test their conjecture on another experiment.

Experiment:

A bucket contains

  • two yellow blocks,
  • four blue blocks, and
  • six red blocks.

The blocks are all the same size. A player chooses a block from the bucket at random.
• What is the theoretical probability the block is yellow? Blue? Red? Which color is most likely to be drawn?

P(Yellow) = 2/12 or 1/6

P(Blue) = 4/12 or 1/3

P(Red) = 6/12 or 1/2

Red is most likely to be drawn.
• What is the sum of the probabilities? Does it agree with the sum of the theoretical probabilities conjecture?

2/12 + 4/12 + 6/12 = 12/12 or 1.

Yes. It makes sense that the sum of the probabilities is 1. You would want to account for all of the possible outcomes. So, all the parts should equal the whole in the ratios.

Situation B. Rodney’s Conjectures

Rodney’s group made some conjectures about drawing blocks in Situation A. Are their conjectures correct? Explain why.

Conjecture 1

The sum of the probability of drawing a blue block and the probability of not drawing a blue block is 1.

Conjecture 2

If we triple the number of each color, the probability of drawing each color is the same as adding 3 of each color.

Incorrect.

When you triple the amount of each color the ratios remain equivalent:

P(Yellow) = 6/36 or 1/6

P(Blue) = 12/36or 1/3

P(Red) = 18/36 or 1/2

When you add 3 more of each color the ratios change.

P(Yellow) = 5/21

P(Blue) = 7/(21 ) or 1/3

P(Red) = 9/21 or 3/7

Conjecture 3

The probability of drawing either a red block or a yellow block is the sum of the probabilities of drawing a red block and drawing a yellow block.

Correct.

The probability of drawing a red is 6/12 of the time and the probability of drawing a yellow is 2/12 of the time, so 8/12 of the time you will get red or yellow.

Another way to look at it is with the counterargument that 4/12 of the time you will get blue so 1 - 4/12 = 8/12.

Conjecture 4

If we add two blue blocks to the bucket, then the probability of drawing a blue block is ½.

Incorrect.

There would now be 14 marbles and 6 would be blue. P(blue) is 6/14.

Conjecture 5

Jakayla says the probability of drawing a blue is 12/4 .

Incorrect.

The correct probability for drawing a blue is 4/12 or 1/3.

The number of favorable events can never be greater than the total number of events, so a probability can never be greater than 1 (although a probability can be equal to 1).

Situation C. Another Bag of Marbles

Ms. Tsao suggests one more experiment. A different bag contains several marbles. Each marble is red or white or blue. The probability of choosing a red marble is 1/3 and the probability of choosing a white marble is 1/6.
• What is the probability of choosing a blue marble? Explain.
P(blue) = 3/6. Total probability is 1. P(red or white) = 1/6 + 1/3 = 3/6 so P(blue) = 1 - 3/6= 3/6
• What is the least number of marbles that can be in the bag?
6 marbles. 1 white, 2 red, 3 blue
• Suppose the bag contains the least number of marbles. How many of each color does the bag contain?
1 white, 2 red, 3 blue
• Can the bag contain 48 marbles? If so, how many of each color does it contain?
Yes. 8 white, 16 red, 24 blue
• Suppose the bag contains 8 red marbles and 4 white marbles. How many blue marbles does it contain?
